author: John Dagge
title: Big Aussie’s bottom line feeling pinch
text:
BHP Billiton has posted its worst profit in more than a decade as a broad slump in commodity prices cuts deep into its bottom line.
The world’s biggest miner has also reduced its forecast for peak steel demand in China and warned investors to brace for more market volatility as the Chinese Government ­restructures its economy.
Net profit at the nation’s biggest company slumped 86 per cent to $US1.91 billion ($2.66 billion) for the year to June, the worst result since 2003, it revealed late on Tuesday. The more closely watched underlying profit, which strips out one-offs, more than halved to $US6.42 billion.
That is the lowest tally since 2004 and well below the $US7.5 billion analysts’ had been expecting.
The hit to the bottom line did not stop BHP from lifting its full-year dividend, with chief executive Andrew Mackenzie saying the mining giant was “resolute” in its commitment to never let payments fall.
BHP would step up its ­ongoing cost-cutting and productivity drive and again cut capital expenditure, Mr Mackenzie said.
Both BHP and rival Rio Tinto have previously said they expect steel demand in China — their biggest customer — to peak at 1 billion tonnes between 2025 and 2030. BHP has now lowered its forecast to between 935 million tonnes and 985 million tonnes by mid-2020.
“In the short term we expect ongoing economic reforms in China to contribute to periods of market volatility,” Mr Mackenzie said on Tuesday.
“And, while we remain confident in the long-term outlook for commodities demand ... we have lowered our forecast of peak Chinese steel production.”
BHP Billiton chief executive Andrew Mackenzie. Picture: Noelle Bobrige
Sharp price drops across all of BHP’s key commodities cut underlying profit by $US15.2 billion.
BHP also booked $US3.2 billion in writedowns, with the bulk linked to its US onshore oil and gas assets and a $US2.1 billion loss stemming from its South32 demerger.
BHP maintained its final dividend at US62c a share, lifting its payout across the year by 2 per cent to $US1.24. A falling Aussie dollar means local investors will pocket a 28 per cent increase.
